intro: Cochlearia anglica var. motelayi, commonly known as the English cochlearia, is a flowering plant native to the British Isles. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers and stipitate glands. The plant typically grows in coastal areas and sandy soils, thriving in maritime climates. Its flowers are usually pink or white, and it produces small, rounded pods that contain several seeds. This variety is distinguished by its slightly different morphology compared to the typical form of Cochlearia anglica.
